results.title: Remembering it all
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall, John Edwards and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “How to Drive”.
Makes a recapitulation of all the points given in the previous eleven films, to show the responsibilities undertaken by a driver to check his car for roadworthiness, and to drive in a sensible, considerate manner by following the system of car control. Features First Constable Geoff Caine as The Driver.

results.title: Remembering country (A)
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission, Film Victoria, Charlotte Seymour, Harold Furber and Kate Gillick
results.brief_description: An autobiographical documentary which tells the story of a member of the ‘stolen generation’ of Aboriginal children of mixed descent. In 1957 at age four, Harold Furber was taken from the desert regions near Alice Springs by the Commonwealth Government, and placed in a Methodist missionary camp on Croker Island, 225 km north-east of Darwin. Telling his story through the use of slides and archival footage taken at the mission during the fifties and sixties, Furber recounts a childhood where his fragile but growing feeling of belonging to a new family and home on Croker Island, was continually shattered by the confusion and sense of loss and pain caused by his separation from his family and his country. Carrying a deep sense of alienation and bitterness into his adult life, Furber attempts through this documentary, to reconstruct his fractured identity by reconnecting with his birthplace and community. Narrated by Harold Furber. Written by Kate Gillick and Harold Furber.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Film Commission, Film Victoria, Charlotte Seymour, Harold Furber and Kate Gillick

results.title: Remembering and forgetting
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
The average human brain can store approximately 100 trillion bits of information as memory. Memory is essential for human survival. It is a complex psychological process influenced by many factors. In this program, Philip Zimbardo examines how memory works, where in the brain memory is located, the difference between long and short term memory and the effect on memory when brain cells are damaged.

results.title: Remembering a champion
results.brief_description:
Made in collaboration with Lockington and Districts Living Heritage Complex, this short, comprising of stills, archival excerpts and narrative commentary, celebrates the memory of Kevin Sarre - a champion in an era when a “gun shearer” was something like a pop star.
Made by Malcolm McKinnon and featuring Margaret O’Brien and Des Pentreath.
Excerpt from Australian Wool Board promotional film reproduced courtesy of the Arnold and Saare family collection and the Australian Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry.

results.title: Remembering
results.creator_credit: Mischa Scorer, Alasdair Clayre, Patrick Lui and Nigel Houghton
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Heart of the Dragon”.
This series documents the historical and cultural traditions of China, showing how attitudes in China today are shaped not only by the doctrines of Marx and Mao but also by ancient beliefs and traditions and by the living memories of recent cataclysmic events. This program seeks to identify what it is that unifies a quarter of the world’s population. Uses both original footage and archive material to give a broad overview of historic and modern China.

results.title: Remembering
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Laura Brearley and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Laura Brearley’s dear friend died of cancer, Brearley took solace in her art, her music and remembering. In doing this, Brearley gave the gift of comfort to many others.

results.title: Remedial reading; Helping you to help your child
results.creator_credit: Bill Cole and Audiovisual Centre, University of Auckland
results.brief_description: Remedial reading: a family affair [22:00] deals with a research project in the Mangere district of South Auckland which aimed to clarify parental willingness to assist their children with reading difficulties, how they could be helped and whether this assistance was of lasting benefit. “Helping you to help your child” [23:00] introduces parents to the essential components in tutoring children: praising, problem solving, pausing and beginnings. The program is directed towards parents of older children who have reading difficulties.
results.title_for_label: Remedial reading; Helping you to help your child

The program is directed towards parents of older children who have reading difficulties.

The program is directed towards parents of older children who have reading difficulties.

results.title: Remedial programming (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: James M. Smith and Davidson Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Specific learning disabilities”.
Shows the combination of three different styles of remedying specific learning difficulties in a special classroom. Practical solutions are offered which are applicable to “normal” classrooms. Suitable for teacher/tertiary levels.
